    How To Gradually Convince Your Team For A Change

    less than 1 minute read

    Change is inevitable for an organization to grow and evolve. If an organization does not change much, there is a good chance that your organization is dysfunctional or unable to improve. However, change is also intrusive and uncomfortable by nature. When stakes are high, the most natural thing to do for leaders is to stick to the methods that have worked in the past. As it is often said, “If it ain’t broken, don’t fix it!” In some cases, proposing a change can initially bring visibly negative impacts to the very problem that you are trying to solve by those changes. So how do we gracefully introduce a change to an engineering team, when you know your ability to propose that change is somewhat limited?

    I faced this challenge when proposing to migrate a unit test framework within my team. Changes in tooling may seem trivial for some, but when you are designing safety-critical, high-volume production software, any small change in the infrastructure can lead to highly undesirable sequence of headaches. More importantly, switching the framework meant throwing out at least some of the existing tests and having to rewrite them, while learning how to use it!

    Updated: April 12, 2022
